name: Black Currant Oil
summary: A plant-based oil rich in gamma-linolenic acid (GLA) and omega-6 fatty acids, studied for its potential benefits in inflammation, skin health, hormonal balance, and mood regulation.
description: Black currant oil is extracted from the seeds of the Ribes nigrum plant. It is a rich source of gamma-linolenic acid (GLA), alpha-linolenic acid (ALA), and other polyunsaturated fatty acids that have anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory properties. Traditionally used for skin conditions, premenstrual syndrome (PMS), and joint health, it has also been investigated for potential mood-stabilizing and neuroprotective effects. Some evidence suggests a role in supporting cardiovascular health and reducing oxidative stress.

metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement, not FDA-approved for medical indications

off_label_uses: Adjunctive treatment in mood disorders (early evidence)
contraindications: Concurrent use of anticoagulants without monitoring
Known allergy to black currant or seed oils

items: Atopic dermatitis and eczema symptom reduction
PMS-related mood swings, breast tenderness, and bloating

sections.text: Black currant oil provides gamma-linolenic acid (GLA), which is metabolized into dihomo-γ-linolenic acid (DGLA). This pathway reduces pro-inflammatory eicosanoids and increases anti-inflammatory prostaglandins, contributing to skin barrier repair, reduced inflammation, and hormonal modulation. Its antioxidant content further reduces oxidative stress and may provide neuroprotective effects.

adult.note: Higher doses sometimes used in studies for skin and PMS symptoms.

sections.geriatric: Similar dosing to adults; monitor for polypharmacy interactions

sections.text: Benefits for PMS or skin conditions may take 6–12 weeks of continuous use. Anti-inflammatory effects accumulate gradually.

serious: Rare increased bleeding tendency when combined with anticoagulants

other: Use with caution in patients with bleeding disorders or those on anticoagulants.
Efficacy is modest; results vary across individuals and conditions.

sections.pregnancy: Limited safety data; avoid high doses
sections.geriatrics: Generally safe with standard dosing; monitor bleeding risk

sections.text: Not required; discontinuation may gradually reduce benefits.

items: Black currant oil is one of the few concentrated natural sources of GLA.
Some small studies suggest benefits in mood and stress regulation, but evidence remains preliminary.
May serve as an alternative to evening primrose oil for GLA supplementation.
